Willy Snug, OF Snug Willy, a. he is
sometimes called, is a good farmer. do not
mean by this that he cultivates a vast deal
of land; but what he undertakes to cultivate.
he manages in the best manner, and reaps
more profit from his small farm, than 9TH
ers dc from their large ones. It is not those
who plant and sow the most, who gather ia
the most abundant harvest.


Willy Snug has nc Improbable land on
his farm. Every rod is required to produce
its due proportion of the yearly crops. Nor
is this unrea sonable. for the ground is we'll
manursd, so we'll titled, and so well fenced,
that in a tolerablc season it cannot help rem
derine good account of itself at the time of
harvest Willy Snug knows as well as any
other man the value of manure. OF course,
he suffers none to be lost, nor indeed any.
out of which manure may be made. You do
not see large heaps of dung lying year after
wear in his barn yard, for want of rrsing
out. He is not afraid of soilins his fingers


with the dung-cart, well knowing that NO
man can keep his hands cleaner Of debts,
wsuits. sheriffs, and the Jail. He has a


sort of hollow scooped out. near his barn.


which he calls "the cqtth-aH," and into
which, straws, weeds ashes, the refuse Of


the wood pile, the cellars and the kitchen,
and whatever else may be converted into


manure, are constantly thrown. The COLI
sequence is, that he carries out of this place
yearly several loads Of excellent manure
THE GOOD FARMER.

The ladies of V2ladolid were so agreeable tha.
| saw much less of the city and its buildings than
l otherwise should have done. In the evening
accompanied them to turtulla, which was at
tended by all the fashion of that place. l really
think there is less of art in the composition of
Spanish women than Of any other people what


ssever. They neithcrpaint nor patch, nor have
those periodical mou!tngs Of feathers which
fashion elsewhere prescribes; but they all dress
nearly alike and in the same ways at all seasons;
that Sonora Maria is only to be distinguished
from Sonora Mariana by countenace more mel
ancholy, by black eyes swimming in more
maiden whitcness, or by figure (Which is ever
gracefully of some what large or smaller mould


The fasquina, or black silk pettcoat, is general
ly bordered at the bottom with black beads, and
SO disposed into an open kind of net work, as to
afford the curious eye the casual fecility of adj.
mring the most beautiful ancle in the world
Their stockings are Of white silk, and they are
never without mantela, Gan ample veil of white
lacc,) which is gracefully flung over their head
and shoulders when they SO abroad, and at other
times adopted as a shawl Small pieces of lead
are attached to the bottom Of the fasqunas,
which accounts for the Ionian elegance of its
foldings and fall. Amidst the many changes that
Spain has undergone, the women alone seem
TO be unchanged. Iattices, and jealouses, and
duennas, and indeed all that used to give love-
making such romantic air in this beyond any
other country, have long since disappeared, but
the passion itself still continues the existence of
Spanish women. 1t is not however, that in
trguing kind ofl love, which we hear ofn France,
where a lady changes her love as easily and as
often as ner gloves; but rather devotion to one
object, which renders them the greatest tyrants
in the world, and makes them exact more adora-
ton than was ever offered up at any idols shrine.
THE LADIES OF VALADoLID.

loved one low in the damp earth-Seneath
the cold clods of the valley--hard it is to re-
feet that this, thy child of peerless beauty,
will never more raise its rosy lips to thine,
in all the fondness OF childhood's warm at
fection. All, these are recoIlections that
weigh upon the soul even to overpowering.
Memory tells thee thou art desoate--it tells,
too, of playful smiles-ot thousand soft
and winning ways that twinc around the
msther's bosom-it tells of the sweet wild

will be its shelter. and the narrow house Its
abiding place-the nursery will no more re-
sound with its gladstone mirth-the cradle in
which it had so often reposed in quietis now
desoiate. Thou weepest. childless mother


The last look. The time is come when
she may gaze once morr upon her sleeping
boy, ere the pail is settled upon his liteless
brow. Oh the bitter agony of that moment
--one long burning kiss upon his marble
forehead, and he is shut from her view! In
the fullness of her grief she says.


No more, my baby, shalt thou lie,


With drowsy smile and half-shut eye,


TlllOWcu upon tily iiolhIi , Siea'tA


Serenely sinking into rest


Thou vert lovelier than the morn of May,


Possessing the brighter charms that youth a.


dorm


But all those beauties now have pass'd away,
And all who knew them once are left to mourn
The opening rose boomed here a little while


Smiling serene beneath summers sky
But can no more mothers sigh begue,


Or wipe the tear from pale afllction's eye.


For God hath laid thee down to sleep,


Like pure heart beneath the deep!


Look abroad, fond mother, upon the ways
of sinful men. and repine no more that God
has made thy child an angel in the regions
of bliss. Now his song mngles with the
Thanksgiving of the blest sanctifed, safe,
and secure from the stormy blasts Of ini-
guilty, with him who is from everlasting!

n was summer The sun shone proudly
down upon the gray mist that rose above the
billows-the blushing charms OF spring were
passed. and the summer glow OF love,lness
had succeeded. The woods were gay and
beautiful-for nature had clothed them IN
all her SURPRISING splendours. The noun
tain stream now run, now rippled, now curl

TIE, RIJI.IAI,

He who knows not what It is to labour
knows not what it is to cnjey. The felicity
of human life depends on the regular pros
ecution of some laudablc purpose or object,
which keeps awake and enlivens all our
powers Our happiness consists much more
in the pursuit. than in the attainment OF any
temporal good. Rest is agreeable; but 1t is
only from preceding labours that rest ac-
ouires its true relish. When the mind is
suffered to remain in continued inaction, all
its powers decay. 1t soon languishes and SICK
ems: but the pleasure which it proposed to
obtain from rest, end in tcdiousness and IN
sipidity. To this, let that miserable set OF
men bear witness, who after spending great
part of their life in active industry, have re-
tired TO what they fancied was to be plea
sing enjoyment Of themselves, in wealthy IN
activity and profound repose, where they ex-
pected to find An elysium, they have found
nothing but dreary and comfortless waste.
Their days have dragged on with uniferm
languor; with the melancholy remembrance,
often returning, Of the cheerful hours they
passed, when they were engaged in the hon
est business and labors of the world.


To enjoy long life, and see many days IS
the universal wish; and as the wish Is
prompted by nature, 1t cannot DC IN itseit uii-
| lawful At the same tiue, sCNSidi VII heu'"
stances concur to temper the eagcrness OF
this wish and to show us that 1t should al
WAYS be formed under due submission to the
wiser Judgment OF Heaven. Who among us
can tell whether, in wishing for the contlnu-
ance of many years on earth We may not only
be wishing for prolongation OF distress and
misery!


You might live. my friends, till YOU had
undergone lingering rounds of severe PAM
from which death would have proved sea-
sonable deliverance. You might live till
your breasts were pierced with many a
wound, from public calamites or private
sorrow. You might live till you beheld the
death of all whom you had loved; till you
survived all those who love you; till you were
left as desolate strangers on earth, In the
midst of a new race, who neither knew you'
nor cared for You, but who wished you off the
stage. OF a nature so ambiguous are all the
prospects which life sets before US, that in
every wish we form relating to them much
reason we have to be satisfied that our times
are in the hands of God, rather than our
own.
LONG LIFE.

is ever leading us astray, impcls US to de-
tect and expose the errors of our rcigh5ors,
and thus triumph in our fancied superiority
We place our character as model, and ev-
erv difference and deficiency receives our
condemnation. Unmindful Of the endless
diversity Of characters; the peculiar consti-
tuition of different minds, and the variety OF
motives which govern human actions, we
mark out one path Of thought and action for
the whole, an attempt as absurd ana I'M
practicable, as to prescribe ono orbit Tor all
the planets which glitter in the frmament.


Charity does not require us to excuse the
vices, or overlook the errors OF a friend
One of the best proofs of friendship is that
affrctionate censorship which watches over
the actions of another, marks his errors, and
sedulously labors for their correction But
it instructs US to bear with atiectionatc sym
pathv those ecccntricities of character, those
fluctuations of temper, and those little ex-
cesses, either of depression, to which all are
subject. We should advise friend with
caution and humanity, and reprove him with
that meekuess which would result from con-
viction that we ourselves are talliole, and
that we frequently require to-day the admo-
ni,ions which we so freely impaired yester-
day. Another important duty is to guard
and defend. The world is prying and cap
tious, and the shafts OF calumny fly too
,hickly to miss even the most spotless char
acter. We need not point out the numer-
Gus occasions which present themselves to
silence the calnmnious hint, and rectify the
cquivocal remark AS the depository OF
his sentiments, and the confident of his Sc
crets, we ought TO guard the character OF a
friend; and without excusing orpalliating his
errors. we may often throw the mantle OF
our protection over his foiblcs

THE CHRISTIAN FEMALE.

"Imagination's gloomlest reverie never
conceived of more revolving OBJECT, than
that of wife and mother, dehling IN her
nerson the fairest work Of her God, and set
ting at nought the holy engagements tor
which he had created her. Her husband
who shall heiyhtcn his joys, and dissipate
his cares, and alleviate his sorrows! She
who has rebbcd him of all joy, who is the

sharpest sorrow! These are indeed the
wife's delights-but they are not hers. Her
children-who shall watch over their bud

of passion and vice! She. in whose bosom
every thing beautiful has wlthered, every

hers Connubial love and maternal tender

its prey-the worm Htemherance."

They set off, party of fourteen in num-
her, and found upwards Of three score ele-
plants encamped on the banks of the Kou-

The elephants awokc them early with

One of the party galloped between the ele

some good shots.


One large bull elephant stationed himself
| in the middle of one of these small bushes;


and at least two hundred rounds were fred


without being able to bring him down. or
make him move form the place in which he


had stationed himself. At every shot he


received he was supposed to blow quantity


Of water into the wound, and then tear up q
large lump of earth to endeavor to stop the
blood. The CATERS do the same thing when


they have been shot-that is, tear up hand
full ofgrass and thurst it into the wounded
place; and it is thought they have learnt this


from seeing the elephants do it.-At length
the great bull dropped. The party then en-


tered the bush, and to their great surprise,

this spot, was, that he had there found


pool of water, with which he had been was


ing his wounds. His height measured sew


enteen feet and three quarters. and his


teeth weighed one hundred and ninety


pounds. Before the days sport was ever

THE MONITOR.
CHARITY.

Here, put on thy finger this ring, love,


And, when thou art far DER the sea,
Perhaps to my mind it will bring, love.


Some thought-some remembrance OF me:
Our moments of rapture and bliss, love,


The haunts where so oft we have met,
These tears, and this last parting kiss, love,


II tells thee, o "dinna forget"
We might look on yon fair moon, love,


Oft gazed on by us with delight,
And think of each other alone, love,


At one sacred hour every night:
But ahl ere she'd rise to thy view love,


To me she long, long would be set,
Then look to this t0fen more true, love,


On thy fnger-and "dinna forget"
Thou mayst meet faces more fair, love.


And charms more attractive than mine;
De moved by more winning air, love,


Or struck by figure more fine;


But should'st thou brighter eye see, love,


Or rrnglets of more glossy jet,


Let this still thy talisman be, love.
Look on it, and "dinna forget"
And o when thou writest to me, love,
The sealing impress with this ring,
And that a sweet earnest will be love,
To which, with fond hope will cling,
That to thy vows will be true love;
That happiness waiteth us yeti
One parting embrace-now adieu love-
This moment l'll never forget!
DINNA FORGET.

Obscure Genius-A new poet has started up
in humble life in Scotland. His name IS hoog-
ers, and he resides in Glasgow lie has wfe
and nine children, which he has supported up
on his wages, which never exceeded twelve shi'-
ling per week. The Montreal Herald contains
two specimens taken from forthcoming vol
ume. One of them is of the simple plalntive
cast, the other full of the rich and joyous OF
Burns. We would give the latter ifit were not
100 Scottish in the dialect. The former is
slightly commonplace, but it is intelligible, and
for weaver, admirable.

to
The world is bright before thee,
Its summer flowers are thine.
It's calm blue sky is DER thee,
Thy bosom Pleasures shrine;
And thine the sunbeam given
To Natures morning hour,
Pure, warm, as when from heaven
1t burst on Eden's bower.
There is song of sorrow,


The dcath-dirge of the gay,
That tells ere dawn of morrow,
These charms may melt away,
The suns bright beam be shaded,
That sky be blue no more,
The summer flowers be faded,
And youths warm promise o'ei.
Believe it not-though lonely
Thy evening home may be;
Though Bcauty's bark can only
Float on summer sea;
Though time thy bloom is stealing.
There's still beyond his art
The wild-flower wreath of feeling,
The sunbeam Of the heart.

The following beautiful poem is from the pen
,f Mr.. Halleck, of New-York, author OF "Croak-
or & Co."-Al,hough it has been published be-
fore, yet it is that kind of poetry which never
tires upon the reader, and as we are desrous OF
preserving it in our columns, we copy 1T from the
volume recently published by Mr.. Halieck.

full articles.article:
Willy Snug, OF Snug Willy, a. he is
sometimes called, is a good farmer. do not
mean by this that he cultivates a vast deal
of land; but what he undertakes to cultivate.
he manages in the best manner, and reaps
more profit from his small farm, than 9TH
ers dc from their large ones. It is not those
who plant and sow the most, who gather ia
the most abundant harvest.


Willy Snug has nc Improbable land on
his farm. Every rod is required to produce
its due proportion of the yearly crops. Nor
is this unrea sonable. for the ground is we'll
manursd, so we'll titled, and so well fenced,
that in a tolerablc season it cannot help rem
derine good account of itself at the time of
harvest Willy Snug knows as well as any
other man the value of manure. OF course,
he suffers none to be lost, nor indeed any.
out of which manure may be made. You do
not see large heaps of dung lying year after
wear in his barn yard, for want of rrsing
out. He is not afraid of soilins his fingers


with the dung-cart, well knowing that NO
man can keep his hands cleaner Of debts,
wsuits. sheriffs, and the Jail. He has a


sort of hollow scooped out. near his barn.


which he calls "the cqtth-aH," and into
which, straws, weeds ashes, the refuse Of


the wood pile, the cellars and the kitchen,
and whatever else may be converted into


manure, are constantly thrown. The COLI
sequence is, that he carries out of this place
yearly several loads Of excellent manure

full articles.headline: THE LADIES OF VALADoLID.
full articles.article:
The ladies of V2ladolid were so agreeable tha.
| saw much less of the city and its buildings than
l otherwise should have done. In the evening
accompanied them to turtulla, which was at
tended by all the fashion of that place. l really
think there is less of art in the composition of
Spanish women than Of any other people what


ssever. They neithcrpaint nor patch, nor have
those periodical mou!tngs Of feathers which
fashion elsewhere prescribes; but they all dress
nearly alike and in the same ways at all seasons;
that Sonora Maria is only to be distinguished
from Sonora Mariana by countenace more mel
ancholy, by black eyes swimming in more
maiden whitcness, or by figure (Which is ever
gracefully of some what large or smaller mould


The fasquina, or black silk pettcoat, is general
ly bordered at the bottom with black beads, and
SO disposed into an open kind of net work, as to
afford the curious eye the casual fecility of adj.
mring the most beautiful ancle in the world
Their stockings are Of white silk, and they are
never without mantela, Gan ample veil of white
lacc,) which is gracefully flung over their head
and shoulders when they SO abroad, and at other
times adopted as a shawl Small pieces of lead
are attached to the bottom Of the fasqunas,
which accounts for the Ionian elegance of its
foldings and fall. Amidst the many changes that
Spain has undergone, the women alone seem
TO be unchanged. Iattices, and jealouses, and
duennas, and indeed all that used to give love-
making such romantic air in this beyond any
other country, have long since disappeared, but
the passion itself still continues the existence of
Spanish women. 1t is not however, that in
trguing kind ofl love, which we hear ofn France,
where a lady changes her love as easily and as
often as ner gloves; but rather devotion to one
object, which renders them the greatest tyrants
in the world, and makes them exact more adora-
ton than was ever offered up at any idols shrine.

loved one low in the damp earth-Seneath
the cold clods of the valley--hard it is to re-
feet that this, thy child of peerless beauty,
will never more raise its rosy lips to thine,
in all the fondness OF childhood's warm at
fection. All, these are recoIlections that
weigh upon the soul even to overpowering.
Memory tells thee thou art desoate--it tells,
too, of playful smiles-ot thousand soft
and winning ways that twinc around the
msther's bosom-it tells of the sweet wild
throbbings of unspeakable bliss, that were
thine, when softly soothing it to slumber
and repose. Now the foliage Of the cypress
will be its shelter. and the narrow house Its
abiding place-the nursery will no more re-
sound with its gladstone mirth-the cradle in
which it had so often reposed in quietis now
desoiate. Thou weepest. childless mother


The last look. The time is come when
she may gaze once morr upon her sleeping
boy, ere the pail is settled upon his liteless
brow. Oh the bitter agony of that moment
--one long burning kiss upon his marble
forehead, and he is shut from her view! In
the fullness of her grief she says.


No more, my baby, shalt thou lie,


With drowsy smile and half-shut eye,


TlllOWcu upon tily iiolhIi , Siea'tA


Serenely sinking into rest


Thou vert lovelier than the morn of May,


Possessing the brighter charms that youth a.


dorm


But all those beauties now have pass'd away,
And all who knew them once are left to mourn
The opening rose boomed here a little while


Smiling serene beneath summers sky
But can no more mothers sigh begue,


Or wipe the tear from pale afllction's eye.


For God hath laid thee down to sleep,


Like pure heart beneath the deep!


Look abroad, fond mother, upon the ways
of sinful men. and repine no more that God
has made thy child an angel in the regions
of bliss. Now his song mngles with the
Thanksgiving of the blest sanctifed, safe,
and secure from the stormy blasts Of ini-
guilty, with him who is from everlasting!


n


The long train of weeping friends gather
ed round fresh dug grave. The coffin
was lowered into It's final resting place-thr
spirit of him who was So lovely here had,
long ere this. crossed the dark waters--and
is safely landed upon the tiowery coast of a
world Of fadeless boom'

full articles.headline: ELEPHANT HUNTING.
full articles.article:
From Scenes and Occurrences in CATER Land


All the party went into the bush, the Hot
tentots first with their large guns, then their
wives. and the gentlemen following. The
first Hottentot frequently spoke TO his com :.
panions in low voice, and was heard to
saw, 'look, look" on enquiring the cause,
he pointed out to them the fresh track OF an
Elephant. The bush became thicker, and
the sun had no power to shine through the
thick foliage; they passed the spot which
the Hottentot marked out as the place
where he had wounded the first elephant,
and soon afterwards they saw the dead buf


falo The party went on resolving to see
the dead elephant, and winding along thro'
the bush till they came to sand hill, the
Hottentots pointed out one Of the carcases al
some distance, lying on another sand hill


but on loking at it for second, it appeared
to move, and the Hottentet discovered that
it was young calf by the side of the COW


The whele party Immediately went on. ane
when within musket shot, they found thai


they were two calves laying by their deat
mother; a piteeus and Interesting sight
The young one rose, and some dogs that th'
Hottentots had incautiously taken into th'
bush, barked violently. 1T this momeh


the bushes moved, and the stupenGous ia


Their stalked in; he looked around him qui


city, and even sorrowfully, and after view
ing the party for a second, he walked on


and was soon hid behind some trees. Ih


situation they had placed themselve in, ha
now become extremely critical, the bus
was continuous for miles in extent, an
i where to ay ia case Of An attack was yer

full articles.headline: TIE, RIJI.IAI,
full articles.article:
n was summer The sun shone proudly
down upon the gray mist that rose above the
billows-the blushing charms OF spring were
passed. and the summer glow OF love,lness
had succeeded. The woods were gay and
beautiful-for nature had clothed them IN
all her SURPRISING splendours. The noun
tain stream now run, now rippled, now curl
inc with it's silver eddies sparkling in the
sun -beam-now smoothly flowed along its
ever-yarying bed, towards its quiet home
Sin the world of waters" The birds war
blcd as sweetly in their green bowers OF
bliss, as if signs and tears were thing u"
known.


There was Joy on earth-the twittering
swallow, as it darted along in sunshine and
shade needed not the wailings Of afflction
and distress-the wild bird, in its noiseless
A;sht. softly silent as falls the snow -fake,
eemed unm,ndfu of woe, as it flashed its
wing across the vision. like the thought OF
dream during the hushed hours Of midnight,
and vanished as suddenly. To me the sight
oftheir ioyous felicity brought no gladncss--
the sounds of their mirth fell cold upon the
beart-it seemed but bitter mockery; and
smoke of days departed The bright and
Laughing skies seemed insensible that they
we're smiling over ruin and decay-that one
of hopes fairest. sweetest flowers, had
drooped and died; and that now-even now
was to be laid in the earth's cold bosom.





Ihad seen the child in guileless beauty,
when it was thing all glowing with health.
innocence, and joy-l had seen i folded IN
the arms of her that bore it, in all the over
whelming fondness OF mothers love. but
now her first-born blessing-her first, last
and only one, slept--not on the soft bosom
oG a mothers stenderness-but with the quiet
dead! Death, death! how lovely canst thou
be! Though pale and lifelcss. it wore
smile passonless and pure. as the cherub Of
|immortality--it had nothing Of the corpse
about it, but its Understanding OF the
grave but its silence. So beautiful it seem
ed-like the spsrtive lamb, decked with
fowerv garland for the sacrifice. coult
fain have lain down by its side in the cold DO
som Of our common mother, in the dark ant
silent valley.
Thou weepest. childless mothcr-ah. wei
, thou mayest-the Son of God wept at tn
! tomb Of his friend-and thou mournest tn
. 6rst-bern, Hard il is for thee to lay th

full articles.headline: LONG LIFE.
full articles.article:
He who knows not what It is to labour
knows not what it is to cnjey. The felicity
of human life depends on the regular pros
ecution of some laudablc purpose or object,
which keeps awake and enlivens all our
powers Our happiness consists much more
in the pursuit. than in the attainment OF any
temporal good. Rest is agreeable; but 1t is
only from preceding labours that rest ac-
ouires its true relish. When the mind is
suffered to remain in continued inaction, all
its powers decay. 1t soon languishes and SICK
ems: but the pleasure which it proposed to
obtain from rest, end in tcdiousness and IN
sipidity. To this, let that miserable set OF
men bear witness, who after spending great
part of their life in active industry, have re-
tired TO what they fancied was to be plea
sing enjoyment Of themselves, in wealthy IN
activity and profound repose, where they ex-
pected to find An elysium, they have found
nothing but dreary and comfortless waste.
Their days have dragged on with uniferm
languor; with the melancholy remembrance,
often returning, Of the cheerful hours they
passed, when they were engaged in the hon
est business and labors of the world.


To enjoy long life, and see many days IS
the universal wish; and as the wish Is
prompted by nature, 1t cannot DC IN itseit uii-
| lawful At the same tiue, sCNSidi VII heu'"
stances concur to temper the eagcrness OF
this wish and to show us that 1t should al
WAYS be formed under due submission to the
wiser Judgment OF Heaven. Who among us
can tell whether, in wishing for the contlnu-
ance of many years on earth We may not only
be wishing for prolongation OF distress and
misery!


You might live. my friends, till YOU had
undergone lingering rounds of severe PAM
from which death would have proved sea-
sonable deliverance. You might live till
your breasts were pierced with many a
wound, from public calamites or private
sorrow. You might live till you beheld the
death of all whom you had loved; till you
survived all those who love you; till you were
left as desolate strangers on earth, In the
midst of a new race, who neither knew you'
nor cared for You, but who wished you off the
stage. OF a nature so ambiguous are all the
prospects which life sets before US, that in
every wish we form relating to them much
reason we have to be satisfied that our times
are in the hands of God, rather than our
own.

is ever leading us astray, impcls US to de-
tect and expose the errors of our rcigh5ors,
and thus triumph in our fancied superiority
We place our character as model, and ev-
erv difference and deficiency receives our
condemnation. Unmindful Of the endless
diversity Of characters; the peculiar consti-
tuition of different minds, and the variety OF
motives which govern human actions, we
mark out one path Of thought and action for
the whole, an attempt as absurd ana I'M
practicable, as to prescribe ono orbit Tor all
the planets which glitter in the frmament.


Charity does not require us to excuse the
vices, or overlook the errors OF a friend
One of the best proofs of friendship is that
affrctionate censorship which watches over
the actions of another, marks his errors, and
sedulously labors for their correction But
it instructs US to bear with atiectionatc sym
pathv those ecccntricities of character, those
fluctuations of temper, and those little ex-
cesses, either of depression, to which all are
subject. We should advise friend with
caution and humanity, and reprove him with
that meekuess which would result from con-
viction that we ourselves are talliole, and
that we frequently require to-day the admo-
ni,ions which we so freely impaired yester-
day. Another important duty is to guard
and defend. The world is prying and cap
tious, and the shafts OF calumny fly too
,hickly to miss even the most spotless char
acter. We need not point out the numer-
Gus occasions which present themselves to
silence the calnmnious hint, and rectify the
cquivocal remark AS the depository OF
his sentiments, and the confident of his Sc
crets, we ought TO guard the character OF a
friend; and without excusing orpalliating his
errors. we may often throw the mantle OF
our protection over his foiblcs

full articles.headline: THE CHRISTIAN FEMALE.
full articles.article:
"Yea, he is altogether Lovely"
! ask'd her when in beauty dressed,
When youthful hope inspired her breast
Where lives he whom thou lowest best


She said--in Heaven.
! ask'd her when she fondly press'd
Her smiling infant to her breast,
Where lives He whom thou lowest best!


She said-in Heaven.
lask'd her when her bloom was lost,
When all her earthly hopes were crossed,
Where lives He whom thou lowest most!


She said-in Heaven.
iask'd her in her dying groan,
Who is the brightest loveliest One'
lis GOD she cried, my GOD alone


And went to Heaven.

full articles.headline: EXTRACTS
full articles.article:
From an Address delivered before the Mas


sachusetts Society for the Suppression Of


Intemperancc. BY Charles Shrague.


"When the husband and father forgets
the duty he once delighted to fulfil, and ny
slow degrees becomes the creature OF IN
temnerance. there enters into his house, the
sorrow that rends the spirit-that cannot be
alleviated, that will not be comforted.


alt is here, above all, where she, who has
ventured every thing, feels that every thing
is lost. Woman, silent-suferlng, devoted
woman. here bends to her dIrest aifilctlon.
The measure of her woe is, in truth, tull,
whose husband is a drunkard. Who shall
protect her, when he is her insuter, her op-
pressor.? What shall delight her. when she
ehr;nks from the sight of his face. and trem-
HES 1t the sound of his voice! The hearth
is indeed dark, that he has made desolate
There. through the dull midnight hour. her
priefs are whispered to herself, her bruised
be.rt hleeds in secret. There while the
rruel author of her distress is drowned IN


distant revelry, she holds her solitary vigil


waiting. vet dreading his return. that VIII


oo,v wiring from her by his unkindness, tears


sv.r more scaldiug than those she shed ovel


lie transxression. To fling deeper gloon


across the present, memory tu'ns oaTn' az,
. hroods upon the past. Like the reco"ec'.ol
70 the sun stricken pilgrim, OF the cool sPr'hl
, that he drank at in the morning, INC JOYS !,
: othe, davs come ovei her, as II only 70 moe,
hsr marched and wearied spirit. one reca''
= .he ardent lover, whose graces won nc
/, from the home Of her snfancy-'he enreP

ver his new born childrcn-and she asks 1t
this can really be him--this sunken being,
who ha. nothing for her but the sot's dis
gushing brutality-nothing for those abash-
ed and trembling children, but the sots dis
gusting example! Can we wonder, that a
mid these agonzing moments, the tender
cords of violated affection should snap asun-
der! that the scorned and deserted wife
should confess, "that there is no killing like
that which kills the hearth" that though 1T
would have been hard for her to kiss for
the last time the cold lips of her dead hus-
band, and lay his body forever in the dust,


it is harder to behold him so debasing lie,
that even his death would be greeted in mer-
Cyl Had he died in the light OF his goodness
bequeathing to his family the inheritance OF
an untarnished name, the example OF virtues
that blossom for his sohs and daughters
from the tomb--tho' she would have wept
bitterly indeed. the tears Of grief would not
have been also the tears of shame, But to
behold him, fallen away from the station ne
once adorned, degraded from eminence to
ignomnv-at home, turning his dwelling to
darkness, and its holy endearments to mock
ery-abroad, thrust from the companion
shin of the worthy, Il self-branded outlaw
this is the woe that the wife feels, and is





over as worse than widowhnod."


| So far the sketch Of the broken-hcarted
wife. The next is saddcr and darker
sketch of soiled loyeliuess and degraded
sweetness.


"There is vet another picture behind,
from the exh hi ition OF which would willing
ly be spared. have vcnturcd to point to
those who daily force themselves before the
ord. but there is one whom the world does
not know of--who hides herself from pry-
ing eyes, even in the innermost sanctuary
of the domestic temple. Shall dare to
rend the veil that hangs between, and draw
her forth? the pricstess dying amid her IN,
holy rites--tte sacrihcer and the sacrihce!
o. we compass sea and land. we brave dan
ger and death, to snatch the poor victim or
bcathcn superstiton from the burning pile
and it is well--but shall we not also save
the lovely ones OF our own household, from
immolatng on this foul altar, not alone the
perishing body, but all the worshipping
eraces OF her sex-the glorious attributes OF
halowed womanhood


"Imagination's gloomlest reverie never
conceived of more revolving OBJECT, than
that of wife and mother, dehling IN her
nerson the fairest work Of her God, and set
ting at nought the holy engagements tor
which he had created her. Her husband
who shall heiyhtcn his joys, and dissipate
his cares, and alleviate his sorrows! She
who has rebbcd him of all joy, who is the
source of his deepest care, who lives his
sharpest sorrow! These are indeed the
wife's delights-but they are not hers. Her
children-who shall watch over their bud
ding virtues, and pluck up the young weeds
of passion and vice! She. in whose bosom
every thing beautiful has wlthered, every
thing vile grows rank' who sha'i teach
them to bend their little knees to devotion,
and repeat their Saviour's prayer against
"temptation'" She. who is herself temp
tation's fettered slave? These are truly


the the mothers labors--but they are not


hers Connubial love and maternal tender


ness bloom no longer for her. A worm has
gnawed into her heart, that dies only with
its prey-the worm Htemherance."

difficult to determine. They were all warm
ed not to run against the wind; and the di-
rection Of the house was pointed OUT, as we'll
as circumstances would allow; but while
they were debating the matter, the dogs
ran in among the young elephants; they set
up deafenng yell, and made directly to-
wards the party, some of whom lay down
by the path, with the hope of seizing the
smallest calf, but they were very glad to
make their escape as they discovered it to
be larger than they expected. The bull ell
ephant, called back by the cry of his young,
again appeared, but totally different in as
quicker, his eyes fierce, his trunk elevated,
and his head appeared three times the size,
NV friend called to the Hottentot to look,
and he Immediately replied in broken Eng
lish, Eyes, Mynheer, dat is dc elephant will
make mems dead" The alarm was extreme,
but while the animal stood hesitating, the
cry Of the young sounded from distant quar-
ter, and the enraged father tosk the short
est cut towards them, crushing the branches
as he stalked along; and the party thus most
providentially escaped. 1t was ascertained
that the elephant had made off towards the
sea.


They went up to the dead elephant, mere
ly to examine it; tor the Hottentots leave
the tusks till the flesh becomes softened, as
it would take up too much time to separate
them. One of these men took cut his knife,
and cut circular piece off the head, about
an inch deep; he then pointed out dark spot
similar to what is called the kernal in beef,
this he probed with his knife, and brought


out small part of tz9ig, but it was broken.
| He distributed little piece as great favor


then carefully wrapt the remainder up, as


they have an idea that whoever wears it.


can never be killed by an elephant, and this
valuable charm was transferred by my
friend TO me. 1t is remarkable that no nat
uralist has ever noticed this circumstance


There is no outward appearance. and it is
impossible to imagine how it becomes enc
closed, CT of what use it is to the animal.
They set off, party of fourteen in num-
her, and found upwards Of three score ele-
plants encamped on the banks of the Kou-
nap river. 1t was late when the party are
rived, therefore an attempt would have
been useless and dangerous. Large fires
were lighted to keep off lions as we'll as ele-
phants. and the party being much fatigueds
they lay down and slept.


The elephants awokc them early with
breaking and pulling up trees by the roots,
and rolling themselves in the wa
ter, &c. The party Immediately pressed
for the attack, and now commenced the
sport. The elephants, upon receiving the


first shot as ifby mutual consent, gave chase
though not tor above six or seven hundred
yards. This answered the desired effect.
One of the party galloped between the ele
plants and the bush, which they had just left
commencing, at the same time, heavy fire.
which harrassed them to such degree, that
they fed 10 the plains, leaving behind them


thick cover, in which they might have been
perfectly secure from the shots. On those
| plains great numbers of small bushes are
! found at no great distance from each other,
50 that il one party consents to drive the ell
ephant out of one bush, the other will con-
ceal themselves, and by this means may &c.


some good shots.


One large bull elephant stationed himself
| in the middle of one of these small bushes;


and at least two hundred rounds were fred


without being able to bring him down. or
make him move form the place in which he


had stationed himself. At every shot he


received he was supposed to blow quantity


Of water into the wound, and then tear up q
large lump of earth to endeavor to stop the
blood. The CATERS do the same thing when


they have been shot-that is, tear up hand
full ofgrass and thurst it into the wounded
place; and it is thought they have learnt this


from seeing the elephants do it.-At length
the great bull dropped. The party then en-


tered the bush, and to their great surprise,
| found that the reason he would not leave


this spot, was, that he had there found


pool of water, with which he had been was


ing his wounds. His height measured sew


enteen feet and three quarters. and his


teeth weighed one hundred and ninety


pounds. Before the days sport was ever
they had killed thirteen.

THE MONITOR.

CHARITY.
full articles.article:
VHAKTTY.


"a friend should bear friends infrmities."
There is no virtue, in which men are more
ushcient. than in the exercise of that spirit
sicharity, (which heareth all things, and
Ioeeth all things" Though we never
saoaid countenance error. yet ought we to
usv and reprove with tenderness the faults
: W seaeEu. The pride Of our hearts, which

full articles.headline: DINNA FORGET.
full articles.article:
Here, put on thy finger this ring, love,


And, when thou art far DER the sea,
Perhaps to my mind it will bring, love.


Some thought-some remembrance OF me:
Our moments of rapture and bliss, love,


The haunts where so oft we have met,
These tears, and this last parting kiss, love,


II tells thee, o "dinna forget"
We might look on yon fair moon, love,


Oft gazed on by us with delight,
And think of each other alone, love,


At one sacred hour every night:
But ahl ere she'd rise to thy view love,


To me she long, long would be set,
Then look to this t0fen more true, love,


On thy fnger-and "dinna forget"
Thou mayst meet faces more fair, love.


And charms more attractive than mine;
De moved by more winning air, love,


Or struck by figure more fine;


But should'st thou brighter eye see, love,


Or rrnglets of more glossy jet,


Let this still thy talisman be, love.
Look on it, and "dinna forget"
And o when thou writest to me, love,
The sealing impress with this ring,
And that a sweet earnest will be love,
To which, with fond hope will cling,
That to thy vows will be true love;
That happiness waiteth us yeti
One parting embrace-now adieu love-
This moment l'll never forget!

Obscure Genius-A new poet has started up
in humble life in Scotland. His name IS hoog-
ers, and he resides in Glasgow lie has wfe
and nine children, which he has supported up
on his wages, which never exceeded twelve shi'-
ling per week. The Montreal Herald contains
two specimens taken from forthcoming vol
ume. One of them is of the simple plalntive
cast, the other full of the rich and joyous OF
Burns. We would give the latter ifit were not
100 Scottish in the dialect. The former is
slightly commonplace, but it is intelligible, and
for weaver, admirable.

to
The world is bright before thee,
Its summer flowers are thine.
It's calm blue sky is DER thee,
Thy bosom Pleasures shrine;
And thine the sunbeam given
To Natures morning hour,
Pure, warm, as when from heaven
1t burst on Eden's bower.
There is song of sorrow,


The dcath-dirge of the gay,
That tells ere dawn of morrow,
These charms may melt away,
The suns bright beam be shaded,
That sky be blue no more,
The summer flowers be faded,
And youths warm promise o'ei.
Believe it not-though lonely
Thy evening home may be;
Though Bcauty's bark can only
Float on summer sea;
Though time thy bloom is stealing.
There's still beyond his art
The wild-flower wreath of feeling,
The sunbeam Of the heart.

The following beautiful poem is from the pen
,f Mr.. Halleck, of New-York, author OF "Croak-
